Award.AwardTitle: Travel support for engineering graduate students to attend the 86th ACS Colloid and Surface Science Symposium at Johns Hopkins University, June 10-13, 2012

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Proposal Number: 1159052
P.I.: Michael Bevan

This project provides travel support to partially cover costs associated with engineering graduate students and one overseas speaker to attend the 86th ACS Colloid and Surface Science Symposium, June 10-13, 2012.

The symposium will have presentations on topics, session organizers, keynote and plenary speakers. The travel grant will be used for partial support of travel costs of one international speaker and to support engineering graduate students, as well as other invited speakers who are engineers.

Intellectual Merit: The symposium will provide a forum for communicating fundamentally new insights into colloidal and surface science with relevance to existing complex fluids and advanced materials applications as well as emerging nano- and bio- technologies. Due to the broad scope, this meeting will attract diverse disciplines (e.g. Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Materials Science, Physics, etc.) and nearly all major US academic institutions and many leading international institutions. The diversity of the attendees and the talks is further represented by contributions from theoretical, computational, and experimental groups and the participation of scientists and engineers from all sectors including industry, government, and academia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 86th American Chemical Society Colloid and Surface Science Symposium was held at the Homewood campus of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland from June 10-13, 2012. The Symposium was co-organized by Professors Michael Bevan and Joelle Frechette of Johns Hopkins University. There were a couple initiatives at this meeting including the Langmuir student award session, free registration for all organizers and keynote speakers, and reduced rates for students and postdocs. The meeting included 536 attendees, 464 oral presentations, 49 posters, 4 plenary lectures, 13 technical symposia, and participants from 186 institutions and 18 countries.

Two plenary lectures and two award lectures were presented as part of the meeting. All were held in Shriver Hall in the engineering quad with an approximate capacity of 700 people. The symposia topics were chosen to be representative of the fundamental topics covered at past colloids meetings. The oral sessions were held in three adjacent buildings in the engineering quad of the Johns Hopkins Homewood campus. All symposia were well-supported during abstract submission. A total of 513 papers were presented at the meeting: 464 oral (including four plenary and award lectures) and 49 posters. Each symposium had two co-organizers. One organizer was from industry, one was from a government lab, two were alumni of JHU, 9 were professors at JHU, and 19 were from institutions other than JHU. Each technical symposium featured two invited keynote speakers.

The intellectual merit of this meeting is that it provided a forum for communicating fundamentally new insights into colloidal and surface science with relevance to existing complex fluids and advanced materials applications as well as emerging nano- and bio- technologies. The broader impact of this funding is that it ensured the participation and attendance of graduate students at our symposium, and thus impacted the education and training of future researchers.
